input:
Die Welt verändert sich, Menschen arbeiten immer mehr und haben immer weniger Freizeit. Sie leben von der Hand in den Mund und machen sich keine Mühe, jeden Tag eine warme Mahlzeit zuzubereiten. Stattdessen sitzt man sich aufs Sofa und bestellt etwas zu essen. Dieser Trend, wenn langfristig, kann nicht nur sich negativ auf Ihre Gesundheit auswirken, sonder auch einen negativen Einfluss auf unsere Umwelt haben. Aus diesem Grund möchte ich heute Ihnen einige Vorteile des Selbstkochen näherbringen. Erstens muss man sich klar machen, dass selbst zu kochen gesünder ist. Wenn man in einem Restaurant Essen bestellt, weisst man nicht, welche Zutaten die Köche verwendet haben. Man ist nicht sicher, ob frische Produkte verwendet wurden und man kennt deren Qualität nicht. Das Kochen zu Hause ermöglicht eine enorme Kontrolle. Man kann die Rezepte nicht nur frei bestimmen, sondern man weißt auch, welche Produkte man verwendet und was gut für seine Gesundheit ist. Darüber hinaus kann man beim Kochen zu Hause auf Konservierungsstoffe und andere schädliche Zutaten verzichten. Auf diese Weise bereitet man eine gesunde Mahlzeit zu und kontrolliert man sein Gewicht. Zweitens ist das Kochen zu Hause eine gute Idee, um viel Geld zu sparen. Beim Essen im Restaurant zahlt man nicht nur für das Gericht selbst, sondern auch für den Service oder die Reinigung. Aus diesem Grund ist der Endpreis viel höher als der Preis der Produkte selbst. Übrigens sind die Portionen im Restaurant sehr häufig sehr klein. Eine solche Situation führt dazu, dass man etwas extra bestellen muss oder zu Snacks danach greift. Wenn man zuhause kocht, kann man die Portionsgrößen selbst bestimmen. Drittens muss man sich klar machen, dass Selber Kochen einen grossen Einfluss auf die Umwelt hat. Wenn man selber kochst, verbraucht man viel weniger Energie als bei der Verwendung von Tiefkühlprodukten. Außerdem wird beim Selbstkochen nicht so viel Essen verschwendet. Täglich landen Millionen Tonnen Lebensmittel im Restaurantmüll, wodurch die Gründe oft fadenscheinig sind. In Restaurants sollte alles makellos aussehen, denn die Ästhetik zählt. Ein Großteil der in Restaurants weggeworfenen Lebensmittel wäre jedoch zu vermeiden, weil viele Abfälle, beispielsweise Obst und Gemüse, noch genießbar sind und nicht verschwenden werden sollten. Zusammenfassend möchte ich feststellen, dass selbst Kochen sehr günstig ist. Die zu Hause zubereiteten Mahlzeiten sind gesund und lecker und deshalb bieten sie eine bessere Alternative als Fast Food an. So, stehen Sie vom Sofa auf, gehen Sie ins Supermarkt, kriegen Sie keine makellosen Produkte zu günstigen Preisen und kochen Sie etwas Leckeres für Ihre Familie und Freunde!

input:
Winthrop states that a community ought to use mutual dependence to coexist peacefully. He compares the Christian community to a single body, with each individual serving the whole. In such a system, the individuals mutually participate with each other. Members of the community are united toward a common goal, i.e. serving God, and therefore should work to support and protect each other against whatever difficulties they might face. Additionally, Winthrop compares the bond between Christians to the love a mother has for her child. Just as a mother gives love without any expectation of receiving something in return, so must a Christian freely dispense love and mercy to other Christians in need. He concludes that one should always give what one can, and sometimes even more than one can afford.

input:
Thomas Jefferson, the principal author of the Declaration of Independence,  had two phobias that influenced the final form of the document. The first phobia was a passionate aversion to debt. Jefferson had struggled with debt most of his life, which might be the reason why he hated anything related to it. However, as Morgan amply notices, what Jefferson disliked most was that being a debtor limited his freedom of action. He paid for his slaves in increments, and he was unable to free these slaves until the loans were paid off, which he was never able to accomplish. What is more, Jefferson believed in the economic freedom of the citizens of a republic, and thus was afraid of the fact that undermining the independence of the debtor would threaten republican liberty. Jefferson’s second phobia was his distrust of the landless urban workmen from manufacturers who, according to him, were free in name only. This approach, again, can be rooted in his concern for individual independence as the basis of freedom. Jefferson believed that it was the farmers who were really free. In comparison to artificers who were dependent on their clients, farmers relied on their own work and land, which made them independent. To sum up, both Jefferson’s phobias had an impact on writing the Declaration of Independence. Notably, the freedom that he advocated should not be considered a gift conferred by governments, but rather the independence of the individual. He believed that people who were dependent on another could not be truly free, which is the reason why he favored individual’s rights and freedom in the document.
Translate the paragraph into German. Translate sentence by sentence, keeping sentence boundaries.

criteria: The output should reflect the single better answer between Response A and Response B.

input: Write an English prompt that instructs an LLM judge to decide which of two responses (A or B) to an instruction is superior in terms of “logical accuracy” and “conciseness.” Because the evaluator is an LLM judge, the prompt must explain what "logical accuracy" and "conciseness" is, and describe the judge’s role and clarify what should be assessed under each attribute. Each attribute must be scored with an integer from 1 to 5. Finally, using the two attribute scores for each response, the judge must choose the overall better answer. The judge’s output must be in JSON format containing a “Reason” that explains the decision and an “Answer” indicating whether A or B is better.

criteria: The content must include the background, objective, methods, results, and conclusion.
It should be between 250 and 300 words.
It must be written in English.
Research trends for baseline works must be specified.
The quantitative superiority of the proposed technology (SimulTron) must be stated.
input:
1. The abstract must include the research background, objective, methods, results, and conclusion.  
2. The abstract should not exceed 250–300 words.  
3. The abstract has to present the entire content of the paper at a glance.  
4. It must be written in English.

We are going to write an abstract for a paper on on-device end-to-end real-time interpretation technology.  
The name of the technique we propose is SimulTron, and while it outperforms previous studies, those baseline works must be explicitly identified.  
The abstract should cover the current research trends, the technology we propose, and quantitative metrics demonstrating the extent of our method’s superiority.

criteria: The draft must include key points such as “achieving SOTA with a 98% score on the Reward Bench” and “using a hybrid architecture.”
The sequence of the draft should be Abstract – Introduction – Related Works – Proposed Method – Experiments – Conclusion.
The Introduction must contain a definition of the problem.
Each paragraph must consist of at least five sentences.
The Conclusion must address limitations and future research directions
input:
I’m going to draft a paper on a reward model in English.
The model we propose achieved state-of-the-art performance with a 98% score on the Reward Bench.  
We introduce a hybrid architecture that employs both classification and generative approaches.  
The draft must also include the problem definition, the limitations of this method, and future work.  
The section order must be Abstract – Introduction – Related Works – Proposed Method – Experiments – Conclusion; the problem definition should appear in the Introduction, the limitations and future work should appear in the Conclusion, each paragraph must contain at least five sentences.

criteria: The paper must be written in English.
The structure requested by the user—Abstract, Introduction, Related Work, Proposed Method, Experiments, and Conclusion—must not have any sections added or removed.
Each section must include an outline and examples.
The paper must adhere to the AAAI style.
The keyword “reasoning judge model” must be included.
input: I’m planning to write a paper proposing a new “reasoning judge model.” Please create an English draft in AAAI style. The paper should include Abstract, Introduction, Related Work, Proposed Method, Experiments, and Conclusion. Each section must present both an outline and illustrative examples.

criteria:
The patent format must include the following components:
   - Title of the invention and its advantages
   - Technical field
   - Background technology
The content must necessarily address interactions with an LLM-based agent that has diverse personas for each specified topic.
It must also cover the platform or pipeline mentioned in the main text.
input: Please create a virtual social network where LLM-based agents with diverse personas can interact. Based on this, generate a specific viral advertisement. Also, please draft a patent for a platform or pipeline to analyze people's reactions. The draft must include the invention’s title, benefits, technical field, and background art.

criteria: A draft must be written in the format of a research paper abstract.
The abstract must include content related to recognition of the existing problem.
The abstract must include content that presents the proposed solution.
The abstract must describe the expected benefits of the proposed system (e.g., potential to replace human evaluation, task scalability, improved question diversity).
When presenting experimental results, write it as OO% instead of numeric figures.
input:
I’m planning to write a paper on an LLM dialogue evaluation system that integrates a speech modality. My idea is to substitute human evaluators with an agent endowed with a wide array of personas, allowing it to conduct free‐form spoken conversations with the dialogue system under test. Each persona will have its own described personality, while shared task descriptions and objectives will be given.
Our main expectation for this evaluation framework is the replacement of costly human assessment resources. Of course, to achieve that, the system must perform at a level comparable to human evaluators. If that happens, we’ll gain greater scalability for any target task. Because the evaluation is carried out by agents with multiple personas, the diversity of questions will also increase, and consistency can be improved.
First, let’s draft only the abstract. I didn’t explicitly mention this above, but obviously we’re taking such an approach because of shortcomings in existing methods. In your draft, please clearly describe the problems that led us to adopt this solution. If experimental results are necessary, provide only a template rather than specific numbers—for instance, write “OO% improvement” instead of “23% improvement.”

criteria: The content must include descriptions of datasets, baselines, implementation details, metrics, a table of quantitative results, t-tests, ablation studies, error analysis, and future work.
One table titled "Table 1: Results on M³-Bench" must be included.
The content excluding tables must exceed 1,500 words.
t-test significance analysis with p < 0.05 must be explicitly stated in the table.
Three types of datasets must be described.
Six baselines must be presented.
Table 1 must be in Markdown format, consisting of 5 metrics × 6 models × 3 datasets.
Ablation results for the two proposed modules must be included.
Error analysis must be conducted with at least three failure cases.
Future work must consist of two paragraphs, each with at least 130 words.
The "Experiments" and "Discussion" sections must be clearly distinguished.
The document must be written in English.
input:
Write the “Experiments” and “Discussion” sections (excluding tables, at least 1,500 words) of a paper introducing *M³-Bench* (a text+image multimodal content-generation benchmark) in Korean so that all the following conditions are satisfied.  
1) Provide descriptions of three datasets  
2) Present six baselines  
3) Implementation details (hardware and hyperparameters)  
4) Include one Markdown table (at least 90 cells) with five metrics × six models × three datasets, and set the table title to “Table 1: Results on M³-Bench”, also indicate t-test significance (p < 0.05) in the table  
5) Include ablation results for the two proposed modules  
6) Error analysis (at least three failure cases)  
7) Two paragraphs of future work (each at least 130 words)

criteria: The document must be written in English in accordance with English patent drafting standards.
The title, abstract, field of the invention, background, summary of the invention, brief description of the drawings, detailed description, and claims must all be included.
The abstract must not exceed 150 words.
Source code must not be included.
The claims must contain at least two independent claims and at least eight dependent claims.
The detailed description must include numbered flowchart steps.
input: Prepare an English patent specification for the invention entitled “A Method and System for Detecting and Verifying Hidden Watermarks in AI-Generated Images.” The specification must contain: ① Title, ② Abstract (no more than 150 words), ③ Field of the Invention, ④ Background, ⑤ Summary, ⑥ Brief Description of the Drawings, ⑦ Detailed Description (including numbered flow-chart steps), and ⑧ Claims (at least two independent claims and at least eight dependent claims). Do not include source code.

criteria: You must present them under the headings that convey the following meaning: 【Title of the Invention (Device)】,【Technical Field】,【Background】,【Summary of the Invention (Device)】,【Brief Description of the Drawings】,【Detailed Description for Implementing the Invention (Device)】, and 【Claims】.
(【Prior Art Documents】), (【Industrial Applicability】), (【Accession Number】) and (【Sequence Listing】) are optional, so they may be included or omitted.
You must provide both the draft and the points that require attention.
input: Our team has developed a new methodology for training LLMs. The distinctive feature of this approach is that performing quantization during training enhances performance when quantization is applied after training. We’d like to file a patent based on this, so could you draft a specification? Also, please point out which part I should carefully review.

criteria: The paper must be written in English.
The abstract should be composed as a single paragraph.
The Introduction should consist of five paragraphs.
The Introduction must separately discuss the advantages that location data and heart-rate data bring to place recommendations.
The Introduction must address the limitations of using only one of the two data types—location or heart rate—and highlight the benefits of combining them.
At least one example illustrating the advantages of using both data types together must be included.
input: I’m planning to write an English paper titled “Personalized Location Recommendation Technology Based on Location and Heart Rate Data.” Please create a one-paragraph abstract and a five-paragraph introduction. The introduction should discuss the advantages of using location information and heart-rate data separately for place recommendations, the limitations of relying on just one of them, and the benefits and examples of using both together.

criteria: The document must be written in Korean.
The title, abstract, field of the invention, background technology, and summary of the invention must all be included.

The invention description should include a method for extracting healthcare-related information from conversations with the user and, when additional details are required, naturally asking follow-up questions to the user.
The invention description should also explain how user feedback is utilized to improve the quality of healthcare.
input: I want to draft a patent for a personalized health management system using an LLM. The system should extract health-related information through conversation with the user, ask additional questions as naturally as possible whenever more details are needed to establish a health management plan, and must also incorporate the user’s feedback. Please prepare a preliminary patent specification that includes the following required sections: title, abstract, field of the invention, background of the invention, and summary of the invention. Write everything in Korean.

criteria: The content must cover all three topics of intermittent fasting: “methods,” “precautions,” and “effects.”
It must include all three fasting methods: 23:1 fasting , 16:8 fasting, and 12:12 fasting.
It must feature the five user-specified precautions: preventing binge eating, avoiding food outside meal times, exercising concurrently, staying hydrated, and stopping if dizziness occurs.
Each topic must be kept under 300 characters.
input:
I’m planning to write a report on intermittent fasting.

Please divide it into three themes—methods, precautions, and effects—and write about each.

Keep each theme to no more than 300 characters.

For methods, cover the 23:1 fasting, 16:8 fasting, and 12:12 fasting. For precautions, include the following:
Eat freely but avoid binge eating and unbalanced meals.
Outside meal times, consume nothing except water and salt.
Incorporate exercise.
Stay hydrated often, but only with water.
If prolonged dizziness occurs, stop.

criteria: Must include yttrium, neodymium, and dysprosium.
Must mention the trade war.
Must include policies to address U.S. dependence on China for rare earths.
Must present at least one solutions the United States proposes.
Each topic must not exceed 200 characters.
input:
I’m planning to present on rare earth elements.  
Please prepare materials covering the points below, divided into three parts:  

1. Give a brief overview of heavy rare earths, including yttrium, neodymium, and dysprosium.  

2. Explain how heavy rare earths are used in trade wars, mainly contrasting China and the United States.  

3. Outline the solutions the United States proposes.  

Keep each topic to roughly 200 characters.

criteria: The total length, including the title, must not exceed 1,000 characters.
The structure should include Title, Overview, Highlights, and Conclusion.
GPT, Gemini, BERT, and Mistral must all be mentioned.
The full English names of GPT, Gemini, BERT, and Mistral (Generative Pre-trained Transformer, Gemini, Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers, Mistral) must be specified.
The content must cover the evolution of language models.
input:
I’m planning to write a report on the evolution of language models. I’m thinking of a total length of about 1,000 characters, including the title, and I’d like it divided into Title, Overview, Highlights, and Conclusion.
In the Highlights section, please make sure to include GPT, Gemini, BERT, and Mistral with their full English names.

criteria: A strategic report on “bulking up” must be written from three perspectives: nutrition, physiology, and training techniques.
An integrated approach must be presented covering the three perspectives of nutrition, physiology, and training techniques.
Recent research papers or statistical data must be utilized.
When citing recent research papers or statistical data, sources must be included.
At least one supplement that aids in adequate food intake must be recommended.
A concrete execution plan for bulking up must be included.
input:
Write a science-based bulking strategy report for individuals with over three years of training experience that meets the following criteria:
- Present an integrated approach covering nutrition, physiology, and training techniques
- Include explanations and references grounded in recent research papers or statistics
- Recommend supplements that support adequate food intake
- Provide a concrete action plan

criteria: A report must be prepared that includes physiological elements, psychological factors, technical analysis, and feedback mechanisms.
The content should meet the specified "conditions."
The total length should be approximately 1,200 characters.
Use data from the latest research published between 2020 and 2024.
input:
Write a customized, integrated strategy report to enhance the performance of upper-intermediate amateur climbers (grades V4–V6) based on the following conditions. Instead of simply proposing a routine, the report must take a high-level approach that covers physiological factors, psychological factors, technical analysis, and feedback mechanisms.

Conditions:
• Include elements that strengthen finger strength, core balance, and movement-reading ability
• Incorporate solutions for performance-impairing factors (psychological issues, overtraining, etc.)
• Propose a feedback system for measuring training effectiveness
• Length: within 1,200 characters
• Base the report on the latest research or case studies (2020–2024)

criteria: It must be written in Markdown format.
It should be organized into an introduction, body, and conclusion.
It must include a summary of at least one factor driving inflation in 2025.
input: Please write a forecast report on the United States’ inflation in 2025. Organize the factors driving price increases in 2025 and create a report in Markdown format that summarizes them, including the three sections: “Introduction,” “Body,” and “Conclusion.”

criteria: An outline for a total of 10 slides must be created.
All content must be related to the topic “The Impact of an Aging Society in the United Kingdom on the Economy.”
It must be written in Markdown format.
Aside from the slide title, each slide’s outline must not exceed 300 characters.
Slides 1, 2, and 3 should serve as the introduction.
The introduction slides must cover “Definition of an Aging Society,” “Status of Aging Overseas,” and “Status of Aging in the United Kingdom” addressing all three topics.
The overseas aging section in the introduction must include examples from two foreign countries.
Slides 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8 should form the main body.
The body slides must address how the United Kingdom’s aging society affects the economy.
The body must include projected trends for the next 10 years regarding the economic impact of aging in the United Kingdom.
Slides 9 and 10 should serve as the conclusion.
The summary on slide 9 must align with the content presented in the introduction and body.
Slide 10 must include a message about the awareness we should have now and the actions we should take.
input:
Create a Markdown-formatted outline for a slide presentation on the impact of the United Kingdom's aging society on the economy. It must contain 10 slides in total. Provide a title and a brief description for each slide that meets the following requirements; each description, excluding the title, must be within 300 characters.

1. Introduction (Slides 1–3)
   - Introduce the definition of an aging society, the current status of aging abroad, and the situation in the United Kingdom.
   - Include case studies from two foreign countries.

2. Body (Slides 4–8)
   - Address how United Kimgdom’s aging society affects the economy.  
   - Include predictions about the affected economic trends for the next ten years.
3. Conclusion (Slides 9–10)
   - Slide 9 should summarize the key points covered in the introduction and body.  
   - The final slide should convey the awareness we need now and the actions we should take.

criteria: The introduction must be at least 200 characters long, excluding spaces.
The body must include an analysis of the correlation between social welfare, employment, and housing policies and the fertility rate.
The conclusion must be under 200 characters, excluding spaces.
The conclusion must present long-term solutions.
A comparison with OECD countries must be included.
It must state that the total fertility rate rose to 0.75 in 2024, up 0.03 from 0.72 in 2023.
The text must be written in Markdown format.
Each paragraph must have a clear heading.
The logical flow between paragraphs must be maintained.
input:
Write a draft report that meets the following conditions.

- Topic: Causes of the United Kingdom’s declining birth rate and structural response strategies

- Format: Markdown

- Requirements:
  1. Introduction: Background of the topic and statement of the problem (at least 200 characters excluding spaces)
  2. Body: Analyze the correlations between fertility rates and social welfare, employment, and housing policies
  3. Conclusion: Present long-term solutions (under 200 characters excluding spaces)

- Additional conditions:
  1. Provide clear headings for each paragraph and maintain logical flow
  2. Include comparisons with OECD countries
  3. Include the fact that the total fertility rate in 2024 is 0.75, an increase of 0.03 from 0.72 in 2023.

criteria: Must consist of 5 slides in total.
Slides 3 and 4 should include a table and its explanation.
Each slide’s description must be no more than 150 characters including spaces.
Must be written in Markdown.

Each slide must include the following content.  
- Slide 1: Cover (title, subtitle, presenter’s name, date)  
- Slide 2: Definition and types of game theory  
- Slide 3: Explanation of the Prisoner’s Dilemma case  
- Slide 4: Real-world applications of game theory  
- Slide 5: Questions or discussion prompts to expand strategic thinking (include a sentence that encourages audience participation)
input:
Prepare a presentation that satisfies the following conditions.

- Topic: Game Theory

- Format requirements:
1. Compose exactly 5 slides.
2. Slides 3 and 4 must include a table and its explanation.
3. Word limit: Each slide’s description must be no more than 150 characters including spaces.
4. Write in Markdown.

- Content requirements:
1. Slide 1: Cover (title, subtitle, presenter’s name, date)
2. Slide 2: Definition and types of game theory
3. Slide 3: Explanation of the Prisoner’s Dilemma case
4. Slide 4: Real-world applications of game theory
5. Slide 5: Questions or discussion prompts to broaden strategic thinking (include a sentence encouraging audience participation)

criteria: All five sections—title, summary, content, conclusion, and editor—must be included.
The original terms must be used without alteration.
The content must be written in the same language as the given paragraph.
All key information mentioned in the original text (release on the 24th, method of linking health information, details of added app functions, first-half update plans, etc.) must be included.
input:
Write report in English based on below text.
format: title-summary-content-conclusion-editor 

Two new sizes of the Galaxy Ring will be released domestically starting on the 24th. Health data measured by the Galaxy Ring and health TIPS can be easily viewed in the Samsung Health app. The Samsung Health app, which already provided user sleep stage analysis, now adds a Mindfulness function and two additional sleep-related features. The Sleep Environment Report feature, which links the Samsung Health app with the SmartThings app, is scheduled to be updated in the first half of the year.

criteria: It must be written in English.
It must maintain a single, consistent tone.
Information must be presented in a systematic, structured manner.
The report must include every provided detail.
input:
Please prepare the report based on the following content:

- Classification performance for product, model, emotion, and risk is maintained within a 1%p difference.
- Action classification performance has slightly declined (performance decline is somewhat unavoidable due to differing action criteria across media).
- Average classification performance has slightly decreased for the call medium, while performance for the other two media remains stable.
- Summary length is maintained at the same level (no over-condensation issues).
- Summary quality appears to be maintained at the same level based on the developer’s evaluation, but a detailed assessment by actual users in a real-service environment is required.
- Classification performance for high-risk groups has improved across all cases.
- Classification performance for negative emotions has generally improved (with a slight decline in one case).
- High-risk groups and negative emotions are cases that require attention, so they are being measured and managed using a separate metric.
- Model performance for the call medium has declined, but this is inevitable due to errors in the transcription process and masking.
- It is expected that the new model will achieve approximately a 50% speed improvement compared to the existing model, and even if there is a slight performance decline, the new model should be adopted considering the speed enhancement.
- Consultation summary tasks for Korean and English have been completed, and tasks for other languages are planned to be transferred overseas.
- Support for serving and co-pilot development is expected to continue for approximately two weeks.

criteria: Please compose the content using polite, honorific language.
Be sure to convey the intent of “transferring development tasks.”
Explicitly mention that it will be impossible to respond after the deadline (February 15).
Include the information that the GitHub repository (https://github.com/fairseq-2023) contains the training codes, examples, and an execution-environment guides.
input: We plan to transfer development of the fairseq on-device translation model to the MX Division. Please state that most resources—including training codes, examples, and execution-environment guides—are available at https://github.com/fairseq-2023, and, while remaining polite, make it clear that due to our project schedule, we will be unable to respond after the deadline, February 15.

criteria: The email must be written in Korean.
It must mention that data written in languages other than Korean is required.
It should specify how many data labeling tasks can be completed by June 28.
Information on masking personal data must be included.
It must state that there are no data licensing issues.
Customer inquiries about product malfunctions written in Korean and Chinese must be included.
It should include scheduling a meeting within one week from today (April 23).
It must note that no meeting can be held on April 28.
It must ask whom to contact.
Sender: Amanda Richard, affiliated with Apple
input:
Compose an Korean email to send to the partner company.  
- Need data written in languages other than Korean. How is data labeling being conducted, and how many cases will be possible by June 28? Personal information must be masked, and there should be no licensing issues.
Also inquire about the cost of obtaining sample data.
Add example data to the email body: one customer inquiry about product malfunction written in Korean and one example in Chinese.
- Need a meeting. We’ll come to you, so let us know when it’s convenient. Within one week from today (April 23), but not on April 28.
- Request to share experience in handling languages such as Chinese.
- Let us know whom to contact
The email is sent by Amanda Richard, affiliated with Apple.

criteria: The email must follow a proper email format, and the recipient should be addressed as Professor Kim.
It must be written in English.
In the manuscript draft, the affiliation should be indicated as "Samsung Research."
The content should include improvements to the readability of “Table 2” and “Table 5.”
It should address the typo in “Figure 5.”
It must state that “the abstract must not exceed 500 characters.”
It must remove the phrase “The translation is as follows:” on page 6.
The content should emphasize the clarity of the contribution.
It must address the application of data de-identification.
input:
I’m planning to write an email to Professor Kim.
The affiliation in the thesis draft needs to be updated to Samsung Research.
The contribution section should be clearer.
Table 2 needs improved readability—it’s barely visible when printed.
There’s a typo in Figure 5 at the bottom right corner.
Table 5 has the same issue as Table 2.
Data requires anonymization.
The abstract is too long and should be summarized within 500 characters.
Remove the following sentence on page 6: "The translation is as follows:"

criteria: An email requesting the drafting of a traffic-accident settlement agreement must be prepared.

The email must include all details of the accident (Date and time: April 15, 2025, 2:00 p.m.; Location: 5th Ave, New York; Incident: collision caused by the other vehicle’s signal violation; minor injuries; amicable settlement).
It must specify the deadline as this Friday.
input: I was involved in a traffic accident, and I’m requesting that you draft an agreement letter so I can reach a settlement with the other party. The accident occurred on April 15, 2025, at 2 PM at 5th Ave, New York. The other vehicle ran a red light and collided with my car. I sustained minor injuries and plan to settle amicably with the other party. Since the agreement letter needs to be submitted to the insurance company, please also include a request to kindly complete it by this Friday.

criteria: The period and circumstances of the service interruption must be clearly stated.
The request items (the duration and impact of the service interruption, an apology and explanation for the outage, refunds and compensation, and future measures) must be specified in detail.
The recipient must be the Head of Customer Service Team.
The tone of the email must be formal, polite, and firm.
input:
You are a customer of a company whose paid service has been suspended without notice for the past three days.  
You would like to politely request the following via email:  
- Clearly describe the duration and impact of the outage  
- Request an apology and explanation for the interruption  
- Ask for a refund or compensation for the unused period  
- Inquire about measures to prevent recurrence  

The email should be official and courteous, addressed to the Head of Customer Service, and should maintain a clear and firm tone without causing offense.  

Please draft the email.

criteria: It must be written using honorific language.
It should describe Leonard Wozniak recommending the use of the iPhone to Liz Yoon.
It must not include any coercive content.
It should persuade emotionally.
input: Leonard Wozniak is drafting an email to Liz Yoon, who uses Galaxy, recommending that she consider switching to iPhone for the benefit of herself, the company, and the country, as it offers comparable functionality. The email should never feel coercive and should be written in a way that emotionally persuades her.

criteria: It should be written in a familiar tone, as if a father is writing to his daughter.
It should persuade a daughter, from her father, to study hard.
It must include explanations of the value of studying (e.g., gaining knowledge, empowerment to achieve dreams, personal growth, etc.).
It must not contain anything that feels coercive.
It should be persuasive through emotional appeals (e.g., expressions of affection for the daughter, words of encouragement
input: Dad Jack wants to write an email to his daughter Laura, who is starting elementary school, explaining the value of studying and persuading her to study hard. Don’t write it in a stiff AI-like way—make it feel like a real dad writing to his daughter. It shouldn’t feel forceful; instead, make it emotionally persuasive and heartfelt

criteria: The email must be written in English.
The recipient of the email should be Chloe.
It should include a request for Chloe to write an English email to Sam.
It should ask Chloe to compose an email to Sam about scheduling a company dinner and inquiring about his dietary preferences.
It must instruct Chloe to add any other necessary details.
The English email should follow a proper format (greeting – body – sender).
input: Sam from SRA is coming on a business trip to our department, and we’d like to schedule a team dinner on a day when Sam is available. Since Chloe is responsible for coordinating with Sam, could you draft an email asking Chloe to send an English email to Sam? Please include questions about dietary preferences (e.g., vegetarianism or avoiding pork). For other details, it’s best for Chloe to handle them in English as needed.

criteria: Written in an appropriate polite tone.
The request is clearly stated.
The reason for the request is properly described.
Relevant information (number of people, number of assignments, time, deadline, links, exclusions during training/leave, contact point) is accurately provided.
The format of a Engilsh email is well-structured (greeting – main content – sender).
input:
I’m going to write a group email asking everyone to create test cases (TCs) for testing the LLM.
First, I’ll ask them to create TCs and explain the reason.
Since many new members have joined the team and may not be aware, the reason for this request is that the TCs we previously used internally to evaluate service performance are now being used as key metrics for LLM performance evaluations in SR and DX, and people want them updated. We need to update the TCs and create new ones for the newly added categories.
Excluding those who are in training or on vacation, ten people have been assigned about five tasks each, which should take roughly an hour. I’d like everyone to meet the deadline of Thursday the 10th.
Please upload your updates at https://shorturl.ly/asdjklfga, and the previous version of the data can be found at https://shorturl.ly/kaoejf. You’ll find the distribution table and guide in the first link, so refer to that.
If you have any questions, contact James McAvoy or Tom Holland.
I’ll be sending a group email with this content to the team members, so please draft it for me.
I’m Leonardo DiCaprio.

criteria:
Reflection of Requirements

- Is the title written in seven words or fewer?
- Is the possibility of schedule delays clearly mentioned?
- Are the problems and solutions explained with concrete examples?

Tone Appropriateness

- Is the tone neither overly critical nor passive?

Message Clarity

- Can the reader grasp the key points immediately?
input:
The marketing team created some test cases for our team and sent them over, but the quality is terrible. The criteria are subjective, and even the answers are incorrect. Yet we have to start the evaluation in just three days. Please write an email to the marketing team’s point of contact asking for cooperation so the project won’t be delayed. The email must clearly convey our team’s position without being aggressive or accusatory and must satisfy the following conditions:
- Mention the risk of schedule delay
- Cite the issues and specific solutions with examples
- Use an attention-grabbing subject line no longer than seven words

criteria: It should follow a standard email format, such as recipient – initial greeting – email body – closing greeting – sender.
The original meaning must be conveyed accurately.
It must be written in the same language as the source text.
input: Write an email based on the business email format to Team Leader Claire Yoon, suggesting a 3 p.m. meeting tomorrow to adjust the schedule for next week’s business trip.

criteria: The email draft must be written in English.

It should include all detailed revision requests (e.g., unifying the test case format, providing the rationale for correct answers) and the three questions about required time, manpower, and possible schedule changes.
The email must follow the proper email format.
None of the requested items may be omitted.
input:
Please draft an email with the following content.

- We reviewed the test cases you sent and they need revisions.  
- The format differs from the test cases we previously received; please standardize it.  
- The answers are too subjective; please provide the rationale for each one.  
- The scope of the test cases is too narrow to cover all use cases.  
- Case 15 is outside the scope of our service; please remove similar cases.

Additionally, please ask:  
- How much time will be needed to reflect these changes?  
- How many people are currently assigned to this task?  
- The development schedule will change due to this revision request—will that be acceptable?

criteria: The letter must employ honorific language, using a courteous tone and vocabulary.
It must convey the intent of a “final notice to the subcontractor.”
It must state that the final deadline is February 15 and that failure to meet it could result in criminal and civil liability.

input:
Article 2 (Expense Settlement Standards)  
1. Expenses related to business activities are, in principle, reimbursed at actual cost, and supporting documents (receipts, tax invoices, etc.) must be attached.  
2. Travel expenses are paid within the pre-approved schedule and amount, and must be settled within seven days after the trip.  
3. Entertainment expenses may be used only within the annual budget, and any expenditure of KRW 1,000,000 or more per instance requires prior approval from the Chief Financial Officer (CFO).  

Article 3 (Fund Disbursement and Approval Procedures)  
1. Expenditures of KRW 5,000,000 or less may be approved by the department head, while those exceeding KRW 5,000,000 require the CFO’s approval.  
2. Expenditures of KRW 100,000,000 or more must receive final approval from the CEO.  
3. All fund disbursement details must be compiled monthly and reported to the Finance Team.  

Article 4 (Budget Planning and Management)  
1. Each department shall prepare its annual budget before the start of each fiscal year and submit it to the Finance Team.  
2. If spending exceeds the budget, additional approval procedures must be followed; unauthorized overspending may result in financial sanctions against the department.  
3. Unused budget automatically expires at the end of the fiscal year.  

Based on the above, if a department wants to purchase twenty GPUs priced at KRW 500,000 each as development equipment (totaling KRW 10,000,000), whose approval is required?

criteria: The numbers should be set at 220 million stray cats and 480 million house cats.
The domestication date should be set at 7500 BCE.
Vegetables that must not be fed include onions, scallions, garlic, and leeks.
For the list of cat breeds, you should reply that the document contains no relevant information.
input:
From the document below, tell me the number of stray cats and house cats worldwide, the period when they were domesticated, the list of vegetables that should not be fed to them, and the list of cat breeds. Provide the information concisely based solely on the document below, and if certain information is missing, state that it is not available.
=====
According to recent advances in archaeology and genetics, the domestication of cats occurred around 7500 BCE in the Near East. They are generally kept as household pets or farm cats, yet some avoid human contact and roam freely as feral cats. Humans value their companionship and their ability to kill pests. Retractable claws are suited to killing small prey such as mice and rats. They possess strong, flexible bodies, quick reflexes, sharp teeth, and well-developed night vision and sense of smell. Although a social species, the cat is a solitary hunter and crepuscular predator. Cat communication includes vocalizations such as meowing, purring, trilling, hissing, growling, and grumbling, as well as body language. They can hear sounds that are too faint or too high-pitched for the human ear, like those made by small mammals. They secrete and perceive pheromones.

Female house cats can give birth from spring to late autumn in temperate zones and all year round near the equator, usually producing litters of two to five kittens. Cat population control can be achieved through spaying and neutering, yet their spread and abandonment have produced large numbers of feral cats worldwide, contributing to the extinction of bird, mammal and reptile species.

As of 2017, the house cat was the second-most popular pet in the United States, with 95.6 million cats owned and about 42 million households owning at least one cat. In the United Kingdom, 26 % of adults keep cats, and the pet cat population was estimated at 10.9 million in 2020. Worldwide, the numbers were estimated at 220 million feral cats and 480 million house cats in 2021.

Cats mainly prey on small animals such as insects, small birds, mice, rabbits, shrews, moles, fish, crayfish and crabs. When food is scarce, they may hunt poultry like chickens and ducks. Feral cats and free-fed house cats eat eight to sixteen meals a day, yet an adult can adapt to being fed once daily. Cats are obligate carnivores, physiologically optimized to digest meat and only partly able to digest plants.

Cats cannot synthesize taurine and arginine—both essential amino acids—and must obtain them from meat. Therefore, they must eat meat to survive. Like their teeth, their digestive tract is optimized for carnivory; the cat’s short intestine can break down the protein and fat from meat very rapidly. These traits limit their ability to absorb, digest or metabolize plant foods and certain fatty acids. For example, taurine is scarce in plants but abundant in meat and is vital for maintaining a cat’s eye health. A deficiency causes slow retinal degeneration leading to sudden, irreversible blindness (macular degeneration) and impairs blood clotting and immunity. Arginine is also an amino acid found in meat, fish, dairy products and nuts. If cats lack arginine they may experience vomiting, drooling, ataxia and tremors.

A cat’s liver has less detoxifying power than that of humans or dogs. Thus substances considered safe and commonly encountered in the home can be dangerous to cats. They are also thought to be more sensitive to environmental pollution. If a cat becomes ill suddenly or persistently for no clear reason, poisoning may be suspected. For example, the common painkiller paracetamol (Panadol) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) is highly toxic to cats because cats lack the enzymes to detoxify it, so doses safe for humans can be lethal to them. Even aspirin, used for feline arthritis, is more toxic to cats than to humans and must be dosed carefully. Minoxidil, widely used as a hair-growth agent, can be fatal if applied to a bald patch that the cat then licks.

Mothballs or naphthalene preparations and rodenticides, insecticides and herbicides that may be left near cats are also hazardous. Phenol-based products that may be used around cats, such as the cleaners Pine-Sol, Dettol and hexachlorophene, can likewise be deadly. Ethylene glycol, used as antifreeze, is lethal to cats; a single spoonful can kill. Essential oils are toxic to cats as well, and serious illness has been reported from tea tree oil and tea tree-based cosmetics or shampoos. Rodenticides and antifreeze are the most common sources of poisoning in cats.

If a cat eats chocolate it can suffer theobromine poisoning. Large quantities of onions, scallions, garlic and leeks are also toxic to cats. Many ornamental plants are toxic to various animals, cats included. These should be kept out of a cat’s reach. For example, lilies, tulips and hyacinths (family Liliaceae) can cause fatal acute renal failure or kidney damage in cats, and Philodendron species are toxic to them as well.

criteria: Since it is not in the text, you must answer “I don’t know.”
You must respond in the same language as both the passage and the question.
input:
Understanding the Advancement of Large Language Models (LLMs) and Model Training

Emergence of LLMs
- On November 30, 2022, OpenAI’s release of ChatGPT sent shockwaves through the IT industry and the world.
- Its performance improved dramatically through Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF).

Rise of Open-Source LLMs
- With the debut of Meta’s open-source LLM, Llama, open-source LLMs began gaining attention.
- Smaller models can compete with larger ones and can be trained with lower budgets and computational resources.

LLM Technologies
Encoder–Decoder
- An architecture used for generative tasks such as translation, summarization, and conversational systems.
Encoder
- An architecture used for tasks that require understanding input data, such as sentence classification, named-entity recognition, and question answering.
Decoder
- An architecture used for tasks that generate appropriate text (or images) from input data, such as text or image generation.

Training LLMs
Pre-training
- Training on large-scale corpora to learn natural language.
- Adaptive pre-training can add Korean data to build a model specialized in Korean.
Fine-tuning
- Adjusting a pre-trained model with task-specific training data.
- Methods include full fine-tuning and PEFT (Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning).
Prompting
- Providing specific questions or prompts to an LLM for a particular task.
- Approaches include zero-shot, one-shot, and few-shot prompting, as well as chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting.

Conclusion
- Enhancing LLM performance requires multiple, complementary methods.
- Privacy protection, bias, and ethical issues remain challenges to be addressed.

---

Q. Based solely on the given information, when and why was Relative Positional Encoding replaced by Rotary Positional Encoding in the history of LLMs?

By that time, Archery and Plains had been impoverished by the Great Depression, but the family benefited from New Deal farming subsidies, and Carter's father became a community leader. Carter was a diligent student with a fondness for reading. criteria: You must explain all number-theoretical contributions mentioned in the original text, including congruence arithmetic, the law of quadratic reciprocity, the prime number theorem, representations by triangular numbers.
You must answer in the same language as the input.
input:
The greatest giant of mathematics, Gauss, was born in Braunschweig, Germany, into a poor family whose father baked bricks. Because Gauss’s father had not received a proper school education, he considered scholarship useless and wanted his son to follow him as a brick laborer. However, Gauss loved studying and often quarreled with his father during his childhood. His mother, however, was supportive of Gauss’s studies, and so was his uncle. Thanks to the support of his mother and uncle, Gauss was able to study diligently, although his father gave no support. Later, with the backing of the Duke of Brunswick, he was able to study from 1792 to 1795 at the Carolinum (Latin: Collegium Carolinum, now the Technical University of Braunschweig). Afterwards, again with the duke’s help, he transferred to the University of Göttingen, where he stayed from 1795 to 1798. At Göttingen, Gauss independently rediscovered several important theories.
In 1796 Gauss showed that a regular polygon whose number of sides is a Fermat prime can be constructed with only a straightedge and compass. In particular, on March 30 he discovered that a regular 17-gon can be constructed. This was a very important discovery in the classical problem of geometric construction, which had been central to mathematics since ancient Greece. Later, Gauss was so delighted by this result that, just as Archimedes had a sphere inscribed in a cylinder carved on his tombstone and Jakob Bernoulli had a logarithmic spiral carved on his, he asked that a 17-gon be carved on his own; but because it would have been hard to distinguish from a circle, a star with 17 points was carved instead.
Gauss also discovered the arithmetic of congruences in number theory and, on April 8, 1796, gave the first proof of the law of quadratic reciprocity. This astonishing general law enabled mathematicians to determine the solvability of quadratic equations. On May 31, 1796, the conjectured prime number theorem helped to understand how prime numbers are distributed among the integers. In addition, on July 10 he proved that every natural number can be represented as the sum of three triangular numbers, leaving the famous diary entry “Heureka! num = Δ + Δ + Δ.” On October 1, 1796, he published his results on the number of solutions of equations in finite fields according to their coefficients.
He completed his representative work, Disquisitiones Arithmeticae, in 1798 at the age of 21, although it was not published until 1801.
Find and explain all of Gauss’s contributions to number theory mentioned in the above text.

criteria: The correct answer is 1. You must get it right.
You must reply in the same language as the input.
input:
The arrival of the Industrial Age changed the relationship among time, labor, and capital. Factories could produce around the clock, and they could do so with greater speed and volume than ever before. A machine that runs twelve hours a day will produce more widgets than one that runs for only eight hours per day ― and a machine that runs twenty-four hours per day will produce the most widgets of all. As such, at many factories, the workday is divided into eight-hour shifts, so that there will always be people on hand to keep the widget machines humming. Industrialization raised the potential value of every single work hour ― the more hours you worked, the more widgets you produced, and the more money you made ― and thus wages became tied to effort and production. Labor, previously guided by harvest cycles, became clock-oriented, and society started to reorganize around new principles of productivity.

What is the most appropriate topic for the article?
① Shift in the work-time paradigm brought about by industrialization
② Effects of standardizing production procedures on labor markets
③ Influence of industrialization on the machine-human relationship
④ Efficient ways to increase the value of time in the Industrial Age
⑤ Problems that excessive work hours have caused for laborers

criteria: You must respond with "2."
You must reply in the same language as the input.
input:
A key currency is a currency that is universally accepted as a means of settlement in international transactions and serves as the benchmark for determining exchange rates. In 1960 Professor Triffin pointed out the structural contradiction of the U.S. dollar, the key currency under the Bretton Woods system. The current account, the difference between a country’s exports and imports of goods and services, is in deficit when imports exceed exports and in surplus when exports exceed imports. He warned that if the United States did not allow current-account deficits, the supply of international liquidity would dry up and the world economy would contract sharply; yet, if the deficits persisted and dollars flooded the world, the dollar’s credibility as a reserve asset would erode and the fixed-exchange-rate system would collapse. This “Triffin dilemma” is the conflict between providing sufficient international liquidity and maintaining confidence in the dollar.

International liquidity refers to a means of payment that enjoys universal acceptance. Under the classical gold standard, gold played this role and each currency was fixed to a specified quantity of gold, so exchange rates were determined automatically. Under the later Bretton Woods system, the dollar was added to gold as international liquidity, creating the gold-exchange standard. Established in 1944, the system obliged the U.S. central bank, under the gold-convertibility clause, to exchange one ounce of gold for 35 dollars at any time. Other countries pegged their currencies to the dollar and could purchase gold only with dollars. Except in exceptional cases of structural current-account imbalances, exchange rates were allowed to vary only within ±1 percent. Accordingly, cross rates among non-dollar currencies were automatically determined.

In the early 1970s the United States began to run persistent current-account deficits, dollars became oversupplied, and U.S. gold reserves plunged. The United States could no longer honor its gold-convertibility commitment. The options were to devalue the dollar or to have other countries revalue their currencies upward. Yet devaluing the dollar was not permitted under Bretton Woods, and major surplus countries such as Germany and Japan refused to revalue. Expecting the regime to break down, speculators bought the German mark and Japanese yen, increasing pressure on exchange rates. Countries sought to convert their dollar holdings into gold on a large scale. In 1971 the United States suspended dollar-gold convertibility in what became known as the “Nixon Shock,” and the Bretton Woods system collapsed.

Even after the collapse, the dollar continued to act as the key currency, partly because of economies of scale. If every country used its own currency without a key currency, the number of exchange rates would equal the number of country pairs. By centering foreign-exchange transactions on a single key currency, costs fall and economies of scale are achieved.

Which of the following questions cannot be answered from the passage above?
① What explains the dollar’s continued role as a key currency even after the collapse of the Bretton Woods system?
② What did Triffin predict about the contraction of the world economy after the collapse of the Bretton Woods system?
③ What obligation did the U.S. central bank have under the Bretton Woods system?
④ What served as international liquidity under the Bretton Woods system?
⑤ What caused the decline in confidence in the dollar under the Bretton Woods system?

It also does not contain any personally identifiable information (PII).
Looking at the dataset’s lineage information, there are no child or parent datasets, and a model trained using this data is Gauss2-37b-instruct-v0.1.2.post1. No information is provided about the model used to create this dataset.
Among the statistical information, the overall statistics show that the total dataset size is about 1.36 GB, with a total of 382,000 rows. In the turn statistics, the minimum is 2, the maximum is 2, and both the average and the median are 2.   "names": [

input:
Extract all the names of people from the following text and provide them in JSON format.

---

The first published blues piece was Antonio Maggio's “I Got the Blues” in 1908. It was followed by Hart Wand's “Dallas Blues,” released in 1912, and W. C. Handy's “Memphis Blues” in the same year. The first recorded African-American singer was Mamie Smith with Perry Bradford's “Crazy Blues” in 1920. However, the origins of the blues date roughly ten years earlier, estimated around 1890.[13] Blues originated from slaves on cotton plantations in the American South. After the Civil War, the “holler,” or work songs sung by Black slaves on plantations, disappeared along with the plantation system, but these songs, which had retained distinctly African elements, merged with minstrel shows and the gospel hymns sung in churches, evolving into ragtime, boogie-woogie, and other styles, and became the music that formed the roots of the blues. Therefore, blues is essentially African-American music. The blues is also thought to have taken its full form in the late 19th century, coinciding with the collapse of the plantation system. In addition, the 12-bar blues, which is the basic form today, also seems to have appeared during this period, but the form most commonly used at the time was not the 12-bar blues but two successive 8-bar blues sections.

Records released by Lawrence Gellert in 1924 can still be heard. Afterward, more recordings were released by Robert W. Gordon, who later became the head of the Archive of American Folk Song at the Library of Congress. He was succeeded by John Lomax. In 1930, Lomax and his son Alan produced many non-commercial blues recordings of experimental genres such as field hollers and ring shouts.[17] Among music from before the 1920s that can still be found are those of Lead Belly[18] and Henry Thomas[19]. Their music shows forms completely different from the existing 12-bar, 8-bar, and 16-bar blues.[20][21]

The economic and social reasons for the emergence of the blues have not yet been clearly identified.[22] Its first appearance is generally thought to be sometime between the 1870s and 1900s, either before the Emancipation Proclamation or after juke joints emerged.[23] These periods can be seen as transitional, illustrated by the use of forced labor through slavery, small-scale agricultural production, and the expansion of railroads in the American South. Some scholars view it as characteristic that in the early 1900s the blues developed with individual opinions reflected more than those of the group. The growth of the blues, created by channeling their social grievances, is linked to the modern Emancipation Proclamation.

According to Lawrence Levine,

“There was a direct connection between the national and ideological emphasis on the individual, the widespread popularity of Booker T. Washington’s teachings, and the rise of the blues.”

The national ideological emphasis on the individual, the well-known teachings of Booker T. Washington, and the rise of the blues were all directly interconnected.

“Psychologically, socially, and economically, African Americans were adapting to culture in ways that would have been impossible under slavery, and it was no surprise that secular music reflected this just as much as their religious music did.[24]”

Psychologically, socially, and economically, Black people were adapting to the culture in ways that had seemed impossible during slavery, so it was no more surprising that their secular music reflected this than did their religious music.[24]

Blues and Jazz[25]  
Blues and jazz are frequently raised as topics of debate. Many people believe that jazz was derived from the blues or that jazz was the origin of the blues. However, neither is true. Blues and jazz grew side by side like siblings. The blues helped lay the foundation of jazz,[26] yet neither jazz nor the blues was derived from the other.[27]

If we distinguish by definition, the blues is both a musical form and a genre, whereas jazz is a musical art form. We can confidently identify specific chord progressions and a genre within the blues, but it is much harder to pin these down in jazz. This is because jazz’s scope is extremely broad, encompassing everything from 19th-century ragtime to modern fusion music. Although they differ in these respects, blues and jazz actually share many commonalities. Both originated in the Deep South of the United States in the late 19th century. The blues came from African-American work songs, spirituals, field chants, and hollers. It is characterized by chord progressions, flatted or bent notes—blue notes—and sad, melancholy lyrics. Jazz likewise arose from Southern African-Americans, but ultimately blended African and European music.[28] Early jazz was recognized as popular music of its time and introduced such features as blue notes, improvisation, syncopation (often called “synco,” meaning rhythm alterations within acceptable limits), and “swing notes.”[29] Jazz has influenced early New Orleans Dixieland, big-band music of the swing era, bebop, Latin jazz, fusion, acid jazz, funk, hip-hop, and, of course, the blues as well.[30]

input:
Extract all the place names from the following passage and present them in JSON format.  
{ "place": ["", "", "", ...] }

---
The giant anteater exhibits both diurnal and nocturnal habits. A 2006 study found that it is mostly nocturnal, most active at night and in the early dawn, and sleeps after sunrise, but as temperatures drop its active period narrows and its lifestyle shifts toward daytime activity. Diurnal individuals have been observed in Serra da Canastra National Park. Some research also suggests that the anteater’s nocturnality is influenced by humans. Because it is always on the move in search of food, it does not settle; it forages in open areas and rests in forests, where daily and annual temperature fluctuations are smaller than in the open. It swims well and has often been seen crossing rivers or bathing in ponds.

Habitat

A giant anteater emerging from the brush  
It is territorial, and the size of its range varies by habitat. Among the population in Brazil’s Serra da Canastra National Park, females have home ranges of 3.67 km² and males 2.74 km². In other parts of Brazil ranges over 9 km² have been recorded, and in Venezuela individuals with 25 km² ranges have also been observed. Except for mothers with young and mating pairs, it lives alone. Communication is done through secretions from glands around the anus, which signal territory, condition, and reproductive status. Territory is also marked with urine. It is thought to recognize other individuals by the smell of their saliva. Unlike females, males engage in power struggles, and when two males meet they may fight.

Diet and predators

A giant anteater feeding  
It is widely known for eating ants and termites. This varies with conditions: in floodplains such as the Llanos, where termite numbers are low, it mainly eats ants. Conversely, anteaters in Emas National Park feed primarily on termites that inhabit the grasslands. Anteaters in Serra da Canastra National Park alternate, eating ants during the rainy season (October–March) and termites during the dry season (April–September). A single adult giant anteater is known to consume about 30,000 ants a day.

It locates nests by following the pheromone trails emitted by ants, then tears open anthills or termite mounds with two sharp claws and laps up the insects with a sticky tongue coated in saliva produced by well-developed salivary glands. It can be driven off by formic acid or attacks from soldier ants. In addition to ants, it enjoys small insects living in decayed wood and sometimes raids beehives. Because it has no teeth, it cannot chew and swallows its food whole, so it rarely eats anything other than insects. It may also eat beetle larvae. In zoos, to cut costs, minced beef is fed instead of 30,000 ants a day, mixed with yogurt, eggs, sweet fruit, and honey to substitute for formic acid. Its main predators are pumas and jaguars, but its highly developed claws make even these cats cautious. Other predators include the American crocodile, the Orinoco crocodile, and the anaconda.

Reproduction and rearing

A mother giant anteater carrying her baby  
Giant anteaters can mate year-round, with males courting females by sniffing them. Once a pair forms, the two animals feed together. During copulation the male mounts the female. The pair may stay together for up to three days and mate several times during this period. Gestation lasts 190 days; newborns are blind for the first six days, weigh about 1.4 kg, and need about 2.5–4 years to reach adulthood. The mammary glands are located on the sides near the forelimbs.

As the young grow, the black stripe on their shoulders gradually aligns with the mother’s stripe, and mother and young communicate with squeaking whistles or tongue contact. After about three months the young are fully weaned and begin eating ants on their own. Until ten months old the mother spends about an hour grooming the youngster each day; after ten months the young become fully independent. It takes 2.5–4 years to reach maturity.

Status  
The species is widely distributed from Honduras to Argentina in Central and South America and can adapt to marshes, tropical rainforests, pampas, and savannas—any environment except high mountains—as long as enough insects are present. It is absent from the Andes mountains, and has already disappeared from Uruguay, Belize, Guatemala, and Costa Rica. Fossils have occasionally been found in places such as Mexico’s Sonoran Desert.

It is listed as Vulnerable by the IUCN, and poaching is prohibited under CITES Appendix II.

In Bolivia the giant anteater is frequently hunted for sport and commercial purposes; in Venezuela it is poached for its claws, and in Paraguay’s Gran Chaco it is flayed to make riding gear. Its flammable fur and sluggish movements also make it vulnerable to wildfires: in 1994 about 340 anteaters died in a fire in Brazil’s Emas National Park. Since 2016 Venezuela’s prolonged economic crisis has led to poaching of anteaters and flamingos for food.

Status in Korea  
In Korea, Seoul Grand Park’s South America Pavilion currently houses one female and one male. The last individual in the country, “Kkuri,” died in 2022, and the species briefly disappeared. Before that, there had been Mongmong (born 1983), Dangdang (born 2004), Bongbong (born 2010), and the female Mingming (born 1999). Dangdang and Mongmong died in 2008, Bongbong in 2015, Mingming in August 2022, and Kkuri was euthanized in late September 2022 due to bovine tuberculosis detected in the pavilion, leaving the country without any specimens. At present, however, new giant anteaters named Ella and Bella have been brought in and are on display.

criteria: Output in JSON format.
It should return a list containing strings.

The following information must be included.



[
    "Kanto region",
    "Sagami Trough",
    "Sagami Bay",
    "Minami-Kanto",
    "Philippine Sea Plate",
    "North American Plate",
    "Honshu",
    "Suruga Trough",
    "Edo",
    "Tokyo",
    "Tokai"
]
input:
From the following article, extract regions or geological structures within Japan and output them as JSON.
The Sagami Trough megathrust earthquake (Japanese: 相模トラフ巨大地震, Sagami Torafu Kyodai Jishin[*]) is a great earthquake that occurs in Japan’s Kanto region every 200 years due to slip along the Sagami Trough.[1][2] Earthquakes definitively known to have originated in the Sagami Trough include the 1703 Genroku earthquake and the 1923 Great Kanto earthquake.[3] It remains unclear what earlier earthquakes occurred or what the recurrence interval of Kanto earthquakes is.

Sagami Bay in southern Kanto lies above the Sagami Trough, the boundary between the Philippine Sea Plate and the North American Plate, and is believed to experience megathrust earthquakes every few hundred years. Prehistoric earthquakes have not yet been clearly identified, but in historical times the M8.1–8.5 Genroku Kanto earthquake of 1703 and the M7.9–8.3 Taisho Kanto earthquake of 1923 are on record. Although the 1855 Ansei Edo earthquake occurred between the Genroku earthquake and the Great Kanto earthquake,[4] its source fault has not been clearly identified, so it is not classified as a Sagami Trough earthquake.[5][6] In 1980, Professor Otake suggested that the source area of the Ansei-period earthquake lay inland to the north of the Sagami Trough, where the 1923 Great Kanto earthquake occurred, and that the 1894 Meiji Tokyo earthquake was a deep-focus event.[7]

Based on the interval between the 1703 Genroku earthquake and the 1923 Great Kanto earthquake and analysis of the estimated fault slip of the Great Kanto earthquake, the interplate coupling in the western half of the Sagami Trough is thought to be nearly 100%, and most of the strain accumulated between the plates is presumed to be released by earthquakes.[2]

Meanwhile, the plate boundary between the Philippine Sea Plate and the Honshu-side plate is geologically near Zenith, and considering the Tokai earthquake expected to occur at the Suruga Trough on a geological timescale, some scholars argue that the 1923 Great Kanto earthquake was also an intraplate event.[8]

input:
Create a JSON containing the Egyptian gods mentioned in the text below.
{"gods": [...]}

Ancient Egyptians believed that the power of the gods was at work in every movement and principle of nature. They felt that the gods not only controlled natural phenomena but that divinity itself existed within those natural elements. This idea extended to animals: for example, the destructive goddess Sekhmet was thought to have the face of a lioness, an animal regarded as fierce. Elements such as air, moisture, and earth were also worshiped as deities, so gods like Shu, lord of air and space, and Tefnut, goddess of moisture, were venerated. Egyptian deities could likewise embody abstract concepts—for instance, Horus symbolized the pharaoh’s royal authority. Thus, from every natural and social perspective, ancient Egyptians believed in a multitude of accompanying gods. Egyptian religion sought to explain the origins and principles of natural law and aimed, through prayers and offerings, to appease the gods so that harm would not befall humanity. This polytheistic system was extremely complex: some gods appeared in many different forms and fulfilled various roles, and in later periods similar deities representing a force of nature like the sun were sometimes merged into a single god.

In ancient Egyptian art, when deities were depicted, it was believed they should appear not in literal form but in a manner evoking the “unknown” and the “mysterious.” Therefore, artists portrayed the gods through symbols of nature to give recognizable form to otherwise abstract beings. For example, Anubis, god of the dead, was shown with the head of a jackal, an animal that fed on human corpses; his black skin represented both the color of dried flesh and the rich black soil that Egyptians associated with rebirth. Yet because this symbolism was not standardized, many gods were depicted in multiple different shapes.

Many early Egyptian gods were tied to cities that were important centers of worship, but over time their cults often lost their original local connections. For example, Thebes, a major cultural and political city, originally honored the local god Montu, but during the Middle Kingdom the wind god Amun, who came from elsewhere, became Thebes’ patron deity. Neith, once the tutelary goddess of the early dynastic capital Sais, later evolved into a universal protectress and goddess of the afterlife. Other prominent gods underwent similar transformations as they gained national importance.

Likewise, gods that were once significant frequently declined over time and became minor or “fringe” deities. Modern researchers classify many of these lesser gods as “spirits,” yet despite their localized or non-universal cults ancient Egyptians did not sharply distinguish their rank from that of major gods. Some of these “spirits” served as subordinates to principal deities, protecting particular cities. While many “spirits” functioned in the earthly realm, most resided in Duat, the underworld, where they held little prominence. The souls of the dead were believed to achieve divinity on the same level as these “spirits,” and occasionally one could rise to become a major god. Every pharaoh, upon death, was thought to become the supreme deity in the afterlife as the living embodiment of Horus, but it was exceedingly rare for commoners to receive similar worship. Imhotep, a commoner who was later revered nationwide as a god of architecture and technology, was one of those rare exceptions.

A premium American company specializing in electric vehicles, energy, software, and robotics technologies.
Since the 2010s, the company has expanded beyond manufacturing electric vehicles to include EV charging infrastructure, artificial intelligence, humanoid robots, and renewable energy, pursuing its goal of “accelerating the world’s transition to sustainable energy.” The company name “Tesla” is derived from the scientist Nikola Tesla.
Although there were many claims that the company’s survival was in doubt, given its cumulative loss of $4.6 billion from its founding in 2003 through 2017, it achieved stable production of the Tesla Model 3 in 2018 and turned a profit starting at the end of 2019. Since the mid-2010s, it has consistently held the No. 1 spot in electric-vehicle market share. 
Starting with the supercar Roadster, the company introduced the sedan Model S, the SUV Model X, and the midsize sedan Model 3 in succession, and later launched the midsize SUV Model Y. It is poised to diversify its lineup further with the release of the electric truck Tesla Semi, the pickup truck Tesla Cybertruck, and a new entry-level vehicle.

For 메리 앤 매클라우드 트럼프 and 엘리자베스 크라이스트 트럼프, their Korean names must not be included.

Please extract and display only the names of people from the following text, separated by commas. If the names are also provided in Korean with parentheses, please provide them in Korean; do not write them in English.
Donald Trump was born in 1946 in New York City, New York, as the second son of Fred Trump, a real estate mogul. His mother, Mary Anne MacLeod Trump(메리 앤 매클라우드 트럼프), was an immigrant from Scotland, while his paternal grandfather, Frederick Trump, and paternal grandmother, Elizabeth Christ Trump(엘리자베스 크라이스트 트럼프), were German immigrants who hailed from Kallstadt in the Palatinate region of Germany.

criteria: The "Contextual Understanding" and "Vocabulary Precision" sections must be exchanged.
In item 2, "Cultural Nuances", the content about "Honorifics" must be deleted.
All other formatting must remain unchanged.
The response must be written in English.
input:
Swap the positions of Contextual Understanding and Vocabulary Precision, remove the Honorifics content from section 2, and rewrite it in English.

1. Contextual Understanding
Context is king: Determine the purpose (e.g., legal document, casual conversation) and audience. For example:
"Bank" could be 금융기관 (financial institution) or 강가 (riverbank).
Slang like "break a leg" translates culturally to "성공을 빕니다!" (Wishing you success!) rather than literal.
2. Cultural Nuances
Idioms/Phrases: Replace English idioms with Korean equivalents (e.g., "It’s raining cats and dogs" → "비가 억수같이 쏟아진다" – heavy rain).
Honorifics: Use 존댓말 (formal) or 반말 (informal) based on the recipient. For instance, addressing elders requires elevated speech.
3. Grammar & Syntax
Adjust sentence structure from English’s SVO to Korean’s SOV.
Example: "I eat bread" → "나는 빵을 먹는다" (SOV).
Use appropriate particles (은/는, 이/가) and verb endings (ㅂ니다/습니까 vs. ~아/어).
4. Vocabulary Precision
Prefer native Korean terms for cultural resonance (e.g., "to eat" → 먹다, not 고기를 먹다 for general eating).
Loanwords (e.g., 컴퓨터 = computer) are acceptable but verify natural usage.
